reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central support-beam of the essay: the move from “many possible moral catastrophes/axes of value” to “the target is narrow and easy eutopia is unlikely,” especially as framed in sections 2.3–2.4 (many ‘single flaws’ can wipe out most value) and the later claim that easygoing views are a narrow slice of plausible views. If the essay’s way of expanding ‘dimensions’ via moral uncertainty/speculative considerations were illegitimate, the ‘fragility/product-of-factors’ motivation for no-easy-eutopia would be substantially weakened (though the essay also has an independent, more formal section-3 argument about bounded/unbounded value functions that the critique only indirectly touches). Strength: the objection is a real pressure point—some of the essay’s examples are indeed speculative and the argument can feel like ‘add enough vetoes and the target becomes tiny’; the critique rightly demands a principled relevance/plausibility filter for which considerations can dominate value loss. However it doesn’t fully refute the essay because (i) the essay partly anticipates this by emphasizing moral pluralism and that the list is illustrative, (ii) the multiplicative model is presented as a toy model not a derivation, and (iii) section 3’s fussiness claims do not depend mainly on the esoteric examples but on scaling/aggregation properties of value functions. Correctness is fairly high: it’s broadly true that operationalizing plausibility as “anything arguable” would bias toward fussiness, and the critique accurately describes a possible argumentative failure mode. It slightly overstates by implying the essay’s conclusion “depends” on the exotic list; the essay’s formal fussiness discussion is more general. Clarity is high: it identifies the alleged hidden crux and what would be needed to fix it. Dead weight is low; it’s mostly substantive. It largely focuses on one issue (gerrymandered dimensionality/filters), so single-issue is high. Overall, it poses a moderate problem but not a decisive refutation.
title: Inflating moral dimensions by treating speculative considerations as potential vetoes
